caption: Glad it is not open to the wider public and turned into a Disneyland.  Only the French reach such innovation and humanity in domestic architecture.

The City of Paris should purchase this icon of modern architecture and make a permanent public museum of it. It is of equal importance as the creations by Mies van der Rohe, Le Corbusier or Jean Prouve.

A beautiful home for those in the field of design. I went there in 2015 with my architecture class and was blown away by the design. If you’re in related to the field of architecture and design, it is possible for you to get a tour. Otherwise, I’m not sure. Book months in advance!!! This is a beautiful home and I still dream about it.  Pictures of the inside are prohibited and there are areas you will not be able to tour. It’s very strict. But still very worth it.

Thank you so much to the owners for allowing people to come visit this architectural gem! It was a brilliant tour and surpassed my expectations for how cool the building really is in person. Thank you to  our tour guide too who went it to such depth in a small amount of time. I would highly recommend visiting!

Tried to see it, but not visible from the street, and according to the website, tours are only available to architecture students and there's an 8+ month wait. So, basically, it's not possible to actually see this :(
Stunning architectural project with intense attention to detail and wonderfully articulated guided tour.  Highly recommended for Architecture and Interiors.
Impossible to get to unless specific conditions. The people outside (including security) weren’t very helpful to understand the situation. Unfairly exclusive.
Really sad and disgrace you can't even see the exterior.

All good,!!
Magnifiqué

One of the most beautiful houses in Paris, an icon of modernism, is hidden so well inside the 7th arrondissement that even true architecture buffs pass by. La Maison de Verre – Glass House. It was designed by Pierre Chareau in 1930 for the physician Jean Dalsace. In the 1920s, he acquired an 18th-century mansion. The elderly lady on the top floor refused to sell her apartment. Dalsas, not wanting to get bogged down in litigation, demolished only the bottom 3 floors, preserving the neighbor's original top floor. So the glass house was integrated into the contours of the old building. Pierre Chareau was obsessed with new technologies: the use of a steel frame allowed the house to have an open layout and replace load-bearing blank walls with glass ones. 100 years ago this shocked the public. Inside, the space is crammed with mechanisms that still work today. In the 30s, the house was chosen by Parisian bohemians.

As stated in other reviews, the house, which is inside a block, can only be visited under very specific conditions. I hope people don't take the trip at all. And if you plan to come and see it, you have to make the reservation even before the visit to Paris itself.
Invisible… Too bad.
